I believe that same-sex marriage should be legalized. Basically, there is no compelling reason not to. Many people worry that same-sex couples pose a threat to the traditional family, but this is not the case. There are numerous aspects to consider and it is fundamentally different, like two sides of the same coin. Many civil rights issues are at stake, such as property taxes and healthcare, where, for instance, a partner may not be allowed to visit a hospitalized loved one because they are not considered family.

Scientific studies show that same-sex couples have the same success rates in relationships and satisfaction as heterosexual couples. The main issue is that people are hung up on the idea that same-sex couples are asking for church approval, but they are simply seeking legal recognition. If there is no religious involvement, this should not be an issue.

People also worry about adoption and community impacts, but these concerns are unfounded. Children of same-sex couples face bullying in schools and may be treated differently. However, parenting skills are the same regardless of the parents' sexual orientation. Same-sex couples can be just as involved in their communities as heterosexual couples.

The federal government should legalize same-sex marriage in every state. President Bush has strong religious views on this issue, similar to his stance on abortion and stem cell research. Most reasons against same-sex marriage are based on morality, which varies greatly among people. It is unethical to enforce one group's morality over others, especially considering recent controversies about religious phrases in the pledge of allegiance.

Many people are against same-sex marriage due to the belief that gay people are psychologically damaged. However, this is not supported by research from institutions like the American Psychological Association. People should rely on scientific research rather than popular opinion or cultural beliefs.

I was initially okay with the premise but everyone was still very much reeling from the September 11th attacks, and I think that we sort of went into Iraq as a pretext with various reasons leading us into Iraq. I think early on, the Bush administration connected the Iraq war to Osama bin Laden and the September 11th attacks, and asserted that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction, which has since been proven false. This really rubs me the wrong way, and in general, the Iraq war frustrates me. It seems to me that the Bush administration openly lied to the American people and has yet to acknowledge that fact. Even Colin Powell, after his big presentation at the UN, now says he wasn't convinced by the evidence at the time, even when he was presenting it. To me, that's just a breach of duty; I think that's an impeachable offense to lie to the American people like that. I think the Bush administration has a complete disregard for the constitution and has been trying to marginalize it ever since, at least since September 11th. I think they came into office with the intent to go to war. I forget the name of the Treasury Secretary who made that allegation in his book after being probably forced out of his office, but it seems that the younger Bush came in with a blood vengeance kind of feeling against Saddam Hussein because of his father's administration, and I think in the long term, he was hoping to expand our energy supply too, which is also a very underhanded way to do things. I do think it’s gone on long enough. I think there would be problems if we withdrew right now though because there's a good chance that the country would lapse into civil war and even more people would die as a result. I think the alternative that the UN and the United States are moving to at this point seems to be a coalition of nations from the surrounding area like Syria and Saudi Arabia to come in and try to restore order. But I don’t necessarily know that that’s a good idea either because I think in the long term that will also cause more problems because Iraq’s sovereignty will come to be an issue. A major issue there because I think it’s pretty clear that the interim government is dissolving at this point. Just from the news reports I’ve heard it doesn’t seem that the Parliament is very effective at all. That Prime Minister really has no control over the political process or what’s happening. Even Muqtada al-Sadr, the guy we were fighting less than a year ago, his party now holds at least 20 seats in the Iraqi Parliament, and I mean we’re still dealing with a fractious group of radical elements who are vying for control of the government. And I think that the political process is experiencing a lot of friction because of that.

I really don't feel like it's right to make it legal or for a state to even declare it as being legal. I think it's really up to the churches, because in the constitution, it's explicitly stated that there should be a separation of church and state. It's clearly stated, and I feel that trying to enforce any kind of power over it would really be defying what's already been written in the constitution. So, I think that the people trying to make it illegal are choosing one church's beliefs over another, because, as we can see, most Catholics and Christians are against it and don't support it, except for in Boston and some other areas. But I don't think it's up to the government to decide what churches are allowed to make illegal or legal. Separation of church and state has been a key aspect of the constitution and what allows for religious tolerance in the United States. I don't think making an amendment about it would be right at all, and I don't see how it would impact the economy or society.

The war in Iraq was not begun with full honesty by the government towards the American people concerning the reasons for war. Before invading Iraq, the government did not provide clear explanations. The Iraq invasion was linked with the 9/11 terrorist attacks, but in reality, there was not much connection between the two. However, the government leveraged the public's outrage against the 9/11 attacks to initiate the Iraq invasion in 2003. Personally, I am against war, especially a preemptive strike. The Iraq War is reminiscent of the Vietnam War, and the government should have learned from past mistakes. A significant number of American soldiers have died, and the government was not prepared for the aftermath and the power vacuum that followed. The United States removed Iraq's government and attempted to establish a democratic government, similar to what was tried in Vietnam. The government should have known that this would be a long and difficult process, not a clear-cut victory. The same challenges exist today, with ongoing American casualties and efforts to train Iraqi forces to govern their own country. The government underestimated the complexity and duration of the task. The initial optimism that the Iraq intervention would be short and successful was naïve. The war in Iraq is a hard decision to make. During the 2004 presidential election, I considered voting for George Bush to see the task through, but it is difficult to abandon the people we displaced. The large number of American casualties and the costs of continuing the war also need to be considered. The stated reason for invading Iraq was to make it a democratic nation, but why not do the same for other countries? The main reason is oil, as the United States is heavily dependent on Middle Eastern oil. The government's decision-making process regarding Iraq was not thorough enough, as it did not account for the lack of weapons of mass destruction found in Iraq, despite knowing about such weapons in North Korea. I hope that the war ends soon and peace is restored, but it seems unlikely.

When you post something online, it becomes public. As an R.A., I've had to deal with this. Whatever you put out there will influence people's opinions of you. If you talk about harmful activities like blowing things up or shootings, people will take notice, and if the school gets involved, they must take action. If something serious is posted, even if it was meant as a joke, it could be taken seriously by the school. There's no invasion of privacy if you've made something public. If you don't want it seen or certain thoughts about you to be known, don't post it. You can't control how others interpret what you share. I don't think school officials should friend students on these platforms, but if something concerning is reported, they must act. It's the responsibility of those who use such platforms to be aware of privacy laws and to report any dangerous content.

To begin, I believe the war has been prolonged too long. Initially, the goal was commendable—to restore democracy in a country that lacked fair political systems. However, we seem to have lost sight of that original purpose. It now appears we are engaged in the conflict merely to demonstrate our global supremacy. When considering the past, the initial motivation was likely influenced by George Bush's father's unresolved disputes with Saddam Hussein. If the intention was genuinely to establish democracy in a country suffering under a tyrant, that would be a just cause. However, over time, this purpose has been obscured, and our actions have become misguided. We appear to be at war to maintain the status quo of conflict. Additionally, the war has stretched on for too long. The local government should now be capable of managing their own affairs. Our economy is being drained by this prolonged conflict, and we have our own critical issues, such as poverty and infrastructure needs, that desperately require funding. The money spent on this war could be more effectively allocated to address these pressing domestic concerns. It's high time we end this war.

I was raised in a Christian family, so I have a complicated view of homosexuality. I have many gay friends and I don't necessarily agree with their lifestyle, but I believe it should be legalized. I don't think it should be a national issue, but rather something decided by each individual state. It's a matter of personal choice and I don't see how the president, whether Republican or Democratic, should impose their views on the whole country. Instead, states should have the freedom to decide based on their own values and preferences. It's not up to the president to make this decision for everyone. The issue should be handled at the state level to respect the diversity of opinions and beliefs within our country.

Initially, I was all for the war because I was personally affected by 9/11. I wanted to go over there and cause as much disruption as they did here. However, I believe we overlooked many aspects and didn't consider the long-term consequences. We went over there unprepared and without a clear plan, and I think it backfired on us. I don't know; I was all for it at first, but now I'm strongly against it. I don't think it accomplished anything. I think as long as they're fighting each other, they won't be fighting with us. I've almost lost interest in what happens over there due to 9/11. I don't care about their issues anymore. Sometimes I don't think they're human; they fight amongst themselves and can't do anything about it. We definitely went over there unprepared, not knowing what to expect. War is different for them than for us; they're savage when it comes to war, and I don't think they're trying to improve their country. I think they just want us to leave. I think we should just leave. We were more emotional and angry than rational about what this could lead to or how they would react. I think President Bush went to war because the people wanted to go. He declared war on Iraq, but he was coming from a place where we couldn't just let them do that and then rebuild. We couldn't have just let it go, but we could have had a better plan. We didn't have a clear goal in terms of creating order, and there was no unity. I think we were driven by emotion and anger, and that's what we created in turn. I don't think we can change them, and I don't think they'll ever change. I really don't have anything else to say. It's gone on for too long. We're not making enough progress to stay there. I think no matter how long we stay, it will collapse once we leave. We can't stay there forever, and I think we're hurting ourselves by staying there. No, I'm done.

I believe that same-sex marriage should be legalized. Basically, there is no compelling reason not to. Many people worry that same-sex couples pose a threat to the traditional family, but this is not the case. There are numerous aspects to consider and it is fundamentally different, like two sides of the same coin. Many civil rights issues are at stake, such as property taxes and healthcare, where, for instance, a partner may not be allowed to visit a hospitalized loved one because they are not considered family.

Scientific studies show that same-sex couples have the same success rates in relationships and satisfaction as heterosexual couples. The main issue is that people are hung up on the idea that same-sex couples are asking for church approval, but they are simply seeking legal recognition. If there is no religious involvement, this should not be an issue.

People also worry about adoption and community impacts, but these concerns are unfounded. Children of same-sex couples face bullying in schools and may be treated differently. However, parenting skills are the same regardless of the parents' sexual orientation. Same-sex couples can be just as involved in their communities as heterosexual couples.

The federal government should legalize same-sex marriage in every state. President Bush has strong religious views on this issue, similar to his stance on abortion and stem cell research. Most reasons against same-sex marriage are based on morality, which varies greatly among people. It is unethical to enforce one group's morality over others, especially considering recent controversies about religious phrases in the pledge of allegiance.

Many people are against same-sex marriage due to the belief that gay people are psychologically damaged. However, this is not supported by research from institutions like the American Psychological Association. People should rely on scientific research rather than popular opinion or cultural beliefs.

I was initially okay with the premise but everyone was still very much reeling from the September 11th attacks, and I think that we sort of went into Iraq as a pretext with various reasons leading us into Iraq. I think early on, the Bush administration connected the Iraq war to Osama bin Laden and the September 11th attacks, and asserted that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction, which has since been proven false. This really rubs me the wrong way, and in general, the Iraq war frustrates me. It seems to me that the Bush administration openly lied to the American people and has yet to acknowledge that fact. Even Colin Powell, after his big presentation at the UN, now says he wasn't convinced by the evidence at the time, even when he was presenting it. To me, that's just a breach of duty; I think that's an impeachable offense to lie to the American people like that. I think the Bush administration has a complete disregard for the constitution and has been trying to marginalize it ever since, at least since September 11th. I think they came into office with the intent to go to war. I forget the name of the Treasury Secretary who made that allegation in his book after being probably forced out of his office, but it seems that the younger Bush came in with a blood vengeance kind of feeling against Saddam Hussein because of his father's administration, and I think in the long term, he was hoping to expand our energy supply too, which is also a very underhanded way to do things. I do think it’s gone on long enough. I think there would be problems if we withdrew right now though because there's a good chance that the country would lapse into civil war and even more people would die as a result. I think the alternative that the UN and the United States are moving to at this point seems to be a coalition of nations from the surrounding area like Syria and Saudi Arabia to come in and try to restore order. But I don’t necessarily know that that’s a good idea either because I think in the long term that will also cause more problems because Iraq’s sovereignty will come to be an issue. A major issue there because I think it’s pretty clear that the interim government is dissolving at this point. Just from the news reports I’ve heard it doesn’t seem that the Parliament is very effective at all. That Prime Minister really has no control over the political process or what’s happening. Even Muqtada al-Sadr, the guy we were fighting less than a year ago, his party now holds at least 20 seats in the Iraqi Parliament, and I mean we’re still dealing with a fractious group of radical elements who are vying for control of the government. And I think that the political process is experiencing a lot of friction because of that.

I really don't feel like it's right to make it legal or for a state to even declare it as being legal. I think it's really up to the churches, because in the constitution, it's explicitly stated that there should be a separation of church and state. It's clearly stated, and I feel that trying to enforce any kind of power over it would really be defying what's already been written in the constitution. So, I think that the people trying to make it illegal are choosing one church's beliefs over another, because, as we can see, most Catholics and Christians are against it and don't support it, except for in Boston and some other areas. But I don't think it's up to the government to decide what churches are allowed to make illegal or legal. Separation of church and state has been a key aspect of the constitution and what allows for religious tolerance in the United States. I don't think making an amendment about it would be right at all, and I don't see how it would impact the economy or society.

The war in Iraq was not begun with full honesty by the government towards the American people concerning the reasons for war. Before invading Iraq, the government did not provide clear explanations. The Iraq invasion was linked with the 9/11 terrorist attacks, but in reality, there was not much connection between the two. However, the government leveraged the public's outrage against the 9/11 attacks to initiate the Iraq invasion in 2003. Personally, I am against war, especially a preemptive strike. The Iraq War is reminiscent of the Vietnam War, and the government should have learned from past mistakes. A significant number of American soldiers have died, and the government was not prepared for the aftermath and the power vacuum that followed. The United States removed Iraq's government and attempted to establish a democratic government, similar to what was tried in Vietnam. The government should have known that this would be a long and difficult process, not a clear-cut victory. The same challenges exist today, with ongoing American casualties and efforts to train Iraqi forces to govern their own country. The government underestimated the complexity and duration of the task. The initial optimism that the Iraq intervention would be short and successful was naïve. The war in Iraq is a hard decision to make. During the 2004 presidential election, I considered voting for George Bush to see the task through, but it is difficult to abandon the people we displaced. The large number of American casualties and the costs of continuing the war also need to be considered. The stated reason for invading Iraq was to make it a democratic nation, but why not do the same for other countries? The main reason is oil, as the United States is heavily dependent on Middle Eastern oil. The government's decision-making process regarding Iraq was not thorough enough, as it did not account for the lack of weapons of mass destruction found in Iraq, despite knowing about such weapons in North Korea. I hope that the war ends soon and peace is restored, but it seems unlikely.

When you post something online, it becomes public. As an R.A., I've had to deal with this. Whatever you put out there will influence people's opinions of you. If you talk about harmful activities like blowing things up or shootings, people will take notice, and if the school gets involved, they must take action. If something serious is posted, even if it was meant as a joke, it could be taken seriously by the school. There's no invasion of privacy if you've made something public. It's the responsibility of those who use such platforms to be aware of privacy laws and to report any dangerous content.

To begin, I believe the war has been prolonged too long. Initially, the goal was commendable—to restore democracy in a country that lacked fair political systems. However, we seem to have lost sight of that original purpose. It now appears we are engaged in the conflict merely to demonstrate our global supremacy. When considering the past, the initial motivation was likely influenced by George Bush's father's unresolved disputes with Saddam Hussein. If the intention was genuinely to establish democracy in a country suffering under a tyrant, that would be a just cause. However, over time, this purpose has been obscured, and our actions have become misguided. We appear to be at war to maintain the status quo of conflict. Additionally, the war has stretched on for too long. The local government should now be capable of managing their own affairs. Our economy is being drained by this prolonged conflict, and we have our own critical issues, such as poverty and infrastructure needs, that desperately require funding. The money spent on this war could be more effectively allocated to address these pressing domestic concerns. It's high time we end this war.

I was raised in a Christian family, so I have a complicated view of homosexuality. I have many gay friends and I don't necessarily agree with their lifestyle, but I believe it should be legalized. I don't think it should be a national issue, but rather something decided by each individual state. It's a matter of personal choice and I don't see how the president, whether Republican or Democratic, should impose their views on the whole country. Instead, states should have the freedom to decide based on their own values and preferences. It's not up to the president to make this decision for everyone. The issue should be handled at the state level to respect the diversity of opinions and beliefs within our country.

Initially, I was all for the war because I was personally affected by 9/11. I wanted to go over there and cause as much disruption as they did here. However, I believe we overlooked many aspects and didn't consider the long-term consequences. We went over there unprepared and without a clear plan, and I think it backfired on us. I don't know; I was all for it at first, but now I'm strongly against it. I don't think it accomplished anything. I think as long as they're fighting each other, they won't be fighting with us. I've almost lost interest in what happens over there due to 9/11. I don't care about their issues anymore. Sometimes I don't think they're human; they fight amongst themselves and can't do anything about it. We definitely went over there unprepared, not knowing what to expect. War is different for them than for us; they're savage when it comes to war, and I don't think they're trying to improve their country. I think they just want us to leave. I think we should just leave. We were more emotional and angry than rational about what this could lead to or how they would react. I think President Bush went to war because the people wanted to go. He declared war on Iraq, but he was coming from a place where we couldn't just let them do that and then rebuild. We couldn't have just let it go, but we could have had a better plan. We didn't have a clear goal in terms of creating order, and there was no unity. I think we were driven by emotion and anger, and that's what we created in turn. I don't think we can change them, and I don't think they'll ever change. I really don't have anything else to say. It's gone on for too long. We're not making enough progress to stay there. I think no matter how long we stay, it will collapse once we leave. We can't stay there forever, and I think we're hurting ourselves by staying there. No, I'm done.

I believe that same-sex marriage should be legalized. Basically, there is no compelling reason not to. Many people worry that same-sex couples pose a threat to the traditional family, but this is not the case. There are numerous aspects to consider and it is fundamentally different, like two sides of the same coin. Many civil rights issues are at stake, such as property taxes and healthcare, where, for instance, a partner may not be allowed to visit a hospitalized loved one because they are not considered family.

Scientific studies show that same-sex couples have the same success rates in relationships and satisfaction as heterosexual couples. The main issue is that people are hung up on the idea that same-sex couples are asking for church approval, but they are simply seeking legal recognition. If there is no religious involvement, this should not be an issue.

People also worry about adoption and community impacts, but these concerns are unfounded. Children of same-sex couples face bullying in schools and may be treated differently. However, parenting skills are the same regardless of the parents' sexual orientation. Same-sex couples can be just as involved in their communities as heterosexual couples.

The federal government should legalize same-sex marriage in every state. President Bush has strong religious views on this issue, similar to his stance on abortion and stem cell research. Most reasons against same-sex marriage are based on morality, which varies greatly among people. It is unethical to enforce one group's morality over others, especially considering recent controversies about religious phrases in the pledge of allegiance.

Many people are against same-sex marriage due to the belief that gay people are psychologically damaged. However, this is not supported by research from institutions like the American Psychological Association. People should rely on scientific research rather than popular opinion or cultural beliefs.

I was initially okay with the premise but everyone was still very much reeling from the September 11th attacks, and I think that we sort of went into Iraq as a pretext with various reasons leading us into Iraq. I think early on, the Bush administration connected the Iraq war to Osama bin Laden and the September 11th attacks, and asserted that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction, which has since been proven false. This really rubs me the wrong way, and in general, the Iraq war frustrates me. It seems to me that the Bush administration openly lied to the American people and has yet to acknowledge that fact. Even Colin Powell, after his big presentation at the UN, now says he wasn't convinced by the evidence at the time, even when he was presenting it. To me, that's just a breach of duty; I think that's an impeachable offense to lie to the American people like that. I think the Bush administration has a complete disregard for the constitution and has been trying to marginalize it ever since, at least since September 11th. I think they came into office with the intent to go to war. I forget the name of the Treasury Secretary who made that allegation in his book after being probably forced out of his office, but it seems that the younger Bush came in with a blood vengeance kind of feeling against Saddam Hussein because of his father's administration, and I think in the long term, he was hoping to expand our energy supply too, which is also a very underhanded way to do things. I do think it’s gone on long enough. I think there would be problems if we withdrew right now though because there's a good chance that the country would lapse into civil war and even more people would die as a result. I think the alternative that the UN and the United States are moving to at this point seems to be a coalition of nations from the surrounding area like Syria and Saudi Arabia to come in and try to restore order. But I don’t necessarily know that that’s a good idea either because I think in the long term that will also cause more problems because Iraq’s sovereignty will come to be an issue. A major issue there because I think it’s pretty clear that the interim government is dissolving at this point. Just from the news reports I’ve heard it doesn’t seem that the Parliament is very effective at all. That Prime Minister really has no control over the political process or what’s happening. Even Muqtada al-Sadr, the guy we were fighting less than a year ago, his party now holds at least 20 seats in the Iraqi Parliament, and I mean we’re still dealing with a fractious group of radical elements who are vying for control of the government. And I think that the political process is experiencing a lot of friction because of that.

I really don't feel like it's right to make it legal or for a state to even declare it as being legal. I think it's really up to the churches, because in the constitution, it's explicitly stated that there should be a separation of church and state. It's clearly stated, and I feel that trying to enforce any kind of power over it would really be defying what's already been written in the constitution. So, I think that the people trying to make it illegal are choosing one church's beliefs over another, because, as we can see, most Catholics and Christians are against it and don't support it, except for in Boston and some other areas. But I don't think it's up to the government to decide what churches are allowed to make illegal or legal. Separation of church and state has been a key aspect of the constitution and what allows for religious tolerance in the United States. I don't think making an amendment about it would be right at all, and I don't see how it would impact the economy or society.

The war in Iraq was not begun with full honesty by the government towards the American people concerning the reasons for war. Before invading Iraq, the government did not provide clear explanations. The Iraq invasion was linked with the 9/11 terrorist attacks, but in reality, there was not much connection between the two. However, the government leveraged the public's outrage against the 9/11 attacks to initiate the Iraq invasion in 2003. Personally, I am against war, especially a preemptive strike. The Iraq War is reminiscent of the Vietnam War, and the government should have learned from past mistakes. A significant number of American soldiers have died, and the government was not prepared for the aftermath and the power vacuum that followed. The United States removed Iraq's government and attempted to establish a democratic government, similar to what was tried in Vietnam. The government should have known that this would be a long and difficult process, not a clear-cut victory. The same challenges exist today, with ongoing American casualties and efforts to train Iraqi forces to govern their own country. The government underestimated the complexity and duration of the task. The initial optimism that the Iraq intervention would be short and successful was naïve. The war in Iraq is a hard decision to make. During the 2004 presidential election, I considered voting for George Bush to see the task through, but it is difficult to abandon the people we displaced. The large number of American casualties and the costs of continuing the war also need to be considered. The stated reason for invading Iraq was to make it a democratic nation, but why not do the same for other countries? The main reason is oil, as the United States is heavily dependent on Middle Eastern oil. The government's decision-making process regarding Iraq was not thorough enough, as it did not account for the lack of weapons of mass destruction found in Iraq, despite knowing about such weapons in North Korea. I hope that the war ends soon and peace is restored, but it seems unlikely.

When you post something online, it becomes public. As an R.A., I've had to deal with this. Whatever you put out there will influence people's opinions of you. If you talk about harmful activities like blowing things up or shootings, people will take notice, and if the school gets involved, they must take action. If something serious is posted, even if it was meant as a joke, it could be taken seriously by the school. There's no invasion of privacy if you've made something public. If you don't want it seen or certain thoughts about you to be known, don't post it. You can't control how others interpret what you share. I don't think school officials should friend students on these platforms, but if something concerning is reported, they must act. It's the responsibility of those who use such platforms to be aware of privacy laws and to report any dangerous content.

To begin, I believe the war has been prolonged too long. Initially, the goal was commendable—to restore democracy in a country that lacked fair political systems. However, we seem to have lost sight of that original purpose. It now appears we are engaged in the conflict merely to demonstrate our global supremacy. When considering the past, the initial motivation was likely influenced by George Bush's father's unresolved disputes with Saddam Hussein. If the intention was genuinely to establish democracy in a country suffering under a tyrant, that would be a just cause. However, over time, this purpose has been obscured, and our actions have become misguided. We appear to be at war to maintain the status quo of conflict. Additionally, the war has stretched on for too long. The local government should now be capable of managing their own affairs. Our economy is being drained by this prolonged conflict, and we have our own critical issues, such as poverty and infrastructure needs, that desperately require funding. The money spent on this war could be more effectively allocated to address these pressing domestic concerns. It's high time we end this war.

I was raised in a Christian family, so I have a complicated view of homosexuality. I have many gay friends and I don't necessarily agree with their lifestyle, but I believe it should be legalized. I don't think it should be a national issue, but rather something decided by each individual state. It's a matter of personal choice and I don't see how the president, whether Republican or Democratic, should impose their views on the whole country. Instead, states should have the freedom to decide based on their own values and preferences. It's not up to the president to make this decision for everyone. The issue should be handled at the state level to respect the diversity of opinions and beliefs within our country.

Initially, I was all for the war because I was personally affected by 9/11. I wanted to go over there and cause as much disruption as they did here. However, I believe we overlooked many aspects and didn't consider the long-term consequences. We went over there unprepared and without a clear plan, and I think it backfired on us. I don't know; I was all for it at first, but now I'm strongly against it. I don't think it accomplished anything. I think as long as they're fighting each other, they won't be fighting with us. I've almost lost interest in what happens over there due to 9/11. I don't care about their issues anymore. Sometimes I don't think they're human; they fight amongst themselves and can't do anything about it. We definitely went over there unprepared, not knowing what to expect. War is different for them than for us; they're savage when it comes to war, and I don't think they're trying to improve their country. I think they just want us to leave. I think we should just leave. We were more emotional and angry than rational about what this could lead to or how they would react. I think President Bush went to war because the people wanted to go. He declared war on Iraq, but he was coming from a place where we couldn't just let them do that and then rebuild. We couldn't have just let it go, but we could have had a better plan. We didn't have a clear goal in terms of creating order, and there was no unity. I think we were driven by emotion and anger, and that's what we created in turn. I don't think we can change them, and I don't think they'll ever change. I really don't have anything else to say. It's gone on for too long. We're not making enough progress to stay there. I think no matter how long we stay, it will collapse once we leave. We can't stay there forever, and I think we're hurting ourselves by staying there. No, I'm done.
